Nice job.  I've actually been doing a large amount of research on comparative financial data programs I can share with you to compare to your program. 
-There was a Quarterly that focused on how to use technology to improve performance and accountability: http://transformgov.org/en/Article/100030/Leveraging_Technology_to_Improve_Performance_Value_and_Accountability_in_Government
-Williamsburg, VA has pioneered a new system to display real-time performance data to the public:  http://transformgov.org/en/Article/101389
/Williamsburg_VA_Pioneers_New_System_to_Display_Realtime_Performance_Data_to_the_Public
-Albemarle County has a similar program:  http://transformgov.org/en/Article/100923/Albemarle_County_VA_Debuts_Performance_Management_Website_for_Increased_Transparency_and_Accountabil
-Rock Hill, SC has a program that has promoted transparency and accountability:  http://transformgov.org/en/Article/100487/CASE_STUDY_Rock_Hill_SC_Launches_3Part_Web_Based_System_for_Accountability_and_Transparency
-The City of Charlottesville uses Clear Point Strategy to publish their scorecards online:  https://www.clearpointstrategy.com/promo/learn-more/index.cfm?page=5
-Miami-Dade County, FL uses ActiveStrategy, Inc. software:  http://www.activestrategy.com/index.aspx
Let me know if this is helpful.
Thanks,
-Greg

author: Thomas Quist
text:
The City of Cartersville recently launched a new Performance Dashboard to help track, analyze, and communicate performance data.  I would love to hear your thoughts on the new dashboard.
A couple of notes:
The dashboard is built in Excel which allows it to be easily distributed as most people have Excel.  Unfortunately, it has only been tested in 2007 and 2010, and it would likely fail in prior versions of Excel.
The dashboard relies heavily on visual basic ("macros") so it is important to enable macros when you open the file.
You will want to read the Introduction page for a few tips on how to use the dashboard and interpret the charts.  I realize that there is a lot to be desired on my intro page, and I plan to beef that up a bit in the future.
Note that you can click on the "sparkline" charts for a blown up, detailed view of the measures with some additional information provided.  Click anywhere on the screen (within Excel) to hide the detail and get back to the dashboard.  I haven't yet completed all of the measure descriptions, so you'll see a lot of placeholders throughout the detail views.
Several of our measures have only been tracked since July, so there is no historical data - this should be fairly obvious.  The fiscal year to date charts ("bullet charts") include only one month of data at this time as the fiscal year began in July.
It is brand new and it's fairly complex, so I do expect a few bugs to emerge as it makes its way across various user's computers.  
Please be honest in your feedback - my feelings won't be hurt.  I'd like to improve this as much as possible.  Keep in mind that the target audience is department heads, the city manager, supervisors, city council members, and the general public will have access as well.  I realize that the general public might find this a bit overwhelming, so I may be creating an alternate version in the future.  As for the others, I plan to offer some basic training on how to read and use the dashboard.
Thanks, and I look forward to your responses.
Sincerely,
Tom Quist
Assistant to the City Manager
City of Cartersville, GA
P.S. I'm always happy to discuss this type of thing over the phone, so if you are interested in calling, please feel free to do so.  I can be reached at (770)607-2111, or via email at tquist@cityofcartersville.org.
